questions.text:
A 35-year-old man comes to the emergency department with fever, chills, dyspnea, and a productive cough. His symptoms began suddenly 2 days ago. He was diagnosed with HIV 4 years ago and has been on triple antiretroviral therapy since then. He smokes one pack of cigarettes daily. He is 181 cm (5 ft 11 in) tall and weighs 69 kg (152 lb); BMI is 21 kg/m2. He lives in Illinois and works as a carpenter. His temperature is 38.8°C (101.8°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 24/min, and blood pressure is 105/74 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 92%. Examination reveals crackles over the right lower lung base. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
11.5 g/dL


Leukocyte count
12,800/mm3



 Segmented neutrophils

80%


 Eosinophils
1%


 Lymphocytes
17%


 Monocytes
2%


 CD4+ T-lymphocytes

520/mm3


Platelet count
258,000/mm3



Serum



Na+

137 mEq/L


K+

5.0 mEq/L


Cl-

102 mEq/L


HCO3-

22 mEq/L


Glucose
92 mg/dL


An x-ray of the chest shows a right lower-lobe infiltrate of the lung. Which of the following is the most likely causal organism?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Patients with HIV infection are at an increased risk of developing tuberculosis (TB). The acute onset of symptoms, the absence of night sweats and weight loss, the presence of severe neutrophilic leukocytosis, and the x-ray finding of a right lower lobe infiltrate make TB unlikely. TB infection in patients with HIV typically occurs at CD4+ counts < 400/mm3.
Image Description:

Active pulmonary tuberculosis (TB) typically manifests with systemic (e.g., low-grade fever, night sweats, weight loss, decreased appetite, and malaise) and pulmonary symptoms (e.g., dyspnea, pleuritic chest pain due to pleural effusion, productive cough, and possibly hemoptysis in advanced stages).
Symptomatic TB can occur as a result of primary infection (primary active TB) or reactivation of latent infection (reactivation TB). While symptoms are similar in both conditions, radiographic presentation differs.
Radiographic imaging in primary TB commonly shows a Ghon complex (Ghon focus with its associated lymph node), unilateral hilar lymphadenopathy, and homogenous consolidation with ill-defined borders in the middle and lower lobes. Chest x-ray in reactivation TB typically shows multiple cavities in the upper lobes, calcifications, patchy consolidations, and features fibroproliferative disease (e.g, scarring) due to inflammatory tissue destruction.

B) INCORRECT:

Haemophilus influenzae is the second most common cause of community-acquired bacterial pneumonia among patients with HIV infection.

C) INCORRECT:

Risk factors for histoplasmosis include occupations that involve contact with soil that may be contaminated with bird droppings in endemic areas (states near the Ohio River valley). Although this patient is from Illinois, histoplasmosis is usually asymptomatic or results in an acute, mild, self-limited infection among patients with a normal CD4+ count. Acute diffuse pulmonary histoplasmosis and/or disseminated histoplasmosis may develop in patients with HIV infection who have a CD4+ count < 200/mm3.
Image Description:

(Map based on data from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, 2015)

D) INCORRECT:

Staphylococcus aureus is only the third most common cause of community-acquired bacterial pneumonia in patients with HIV infection. S. aureus is more commonly associated with hospital-acquired pneumonia.

E) INCORRECT:

Cryptococcus neoformans typically causes chronic meningitis in patients with HIV infection when the CD4+ count is < 200/mm3. The absence of headache and focal neurological deficits, and the presence of a high CD4+ count make the diagnosis of C. neoformans infection unlikely.

F) INCORRECT:

Mycobacterium avium complex (MAC) can cause pulmonary infections in HIV patients with a CD4+ count < 50/mm3. The acute onset of symptoms, the absence of night sweats and weight loss, the presence of neutrophilic leukocytosis, and a normal CD4+ count rule out the diagnosis of MAC in this patient.

G) INCORRECT:

Cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection is usually asymptomatic or results in mild, mononucleosis-like infection in patients with a normal CD4+ count. Severe manifestations such as retinitis, colitis, and/or encephalitis may occur in HIV patients with CD4+ counts < 100/mm3, but pneumonia is not usually seen.

CMV pneumonia is, however, a common complication in patients receiving immunosuppressive therapy following organ transplantation and patients who have received total body irradiation for bone marrow transplantation. CMV pneumonia manifests as atypical pneumonia with features such as nonproductive cough and interstitial infiltrates on a chest x-ray.

H) INCORRECT:

Legionella pneumophila can cause a type of atypical pneumonia called Legionnaires disease. Patients with Legionnaires disease typically present subacutely with a nonproductive cough. Clinical indicators of Legionnaires disease include the presence of confusion, relative bradycardia, diarrhea, and hyponatremia. HIV infection alone with a normal CD4+ count is not associated with an increased risk for Legionella infection.

I) CORRECT:

Streptococcus pneumoniae is the most common cause of community-acquired bacterial pneumonia among HIV-positive patients with a normal CD4+ T-lymphocyte count (same as in patients without an HIV infection).

The routine ACIP immunization schedule on pneumococcal vaccination is applicable to individuals with HIV. See “Pneumococcal vaccines” for more information.
Image Description:

CT chest (axial plane; lung window) of a patient with a history of bacterial pneumonia

Opacification of much of the right lower lobe parenchyma is the result of air space consolidation. Pulmonary vessels are obscured and patent airways (air bronchograms, white dashed line) are seen. Consolidation extends to the major fissure (green overlay).

Parenchymal opacification can be caused by fluid or solid material. Major causes in the acute setting include pneumonia, aspiration, edema, and hemorrhage. In the chronic setting, the main causes include invasive adenocarcinoma and alveolar proteinosis.

J) INCORRECT:

Respiratory tract infections with Aspergillus fumigatus would present as allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis (ABPA), aspergilloma, and/or invasive aspergillosis. However, ABPA typically manifests with eosinophilia and features resembling those of bronchial asthma. An aspergilloma would present with a fungal ball on x-ray unlike this patient with a right lower lobe infiltrate. Pulmonary involvement in invasive aspergillosis manifests with severe necrotizing pneumonia which would typically result in hemoptysis and/or chest pain in addition to fever, dyspnea, and a productive cough.
Image Description:

X-ray chest (PA view)

There are diffuse reticulonodular opacities in both lungs with numerous larger nodules interspersed throughout (examples indicated by red rectangle). In the upper zone of the right lung, an ovoid lesion can be seen that is surrounded by a thin rim with normal radiolucency (arrowheads).

This finding is known as the air crescent sign and is characteristic of aspergilloma.

K) INCORRECT:

Pneumocystis jirovecii causes atypical pneumonia in immunosuppressed patients and is the most common opportunistic infection in patients with AIDS (HIV clinical category C). However, P. jirovecii pneumonia usually occurs in patients with a CD4+ count < 200/mm3 and manifests with features of atypical pneumonia such as a nonproductive cough.
Image Description:

X-ray chest (PA view)

Diffuse, bilateral, interstitial opacification (blue overlay) can be seen extending from the hila to the periphery of the lungs.

This appearance is characteristic of PCP infection.
questions.hint: The acute onset of symptoms, a productive cough, and the findings on x-ray indicate a diagnosis of pneumonia. A normal CD4+ T-lymphocyte count makes an opportunistic infection unlikely.

questions.text:
A 36-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 4-day history of fever, malaise, chills, and a cough productive of moderate amounts of yellow-colored sputum. Over the past 2 days, she has also had right-sided chest pain that is exacerbated by deep inspiration. Six months ago, she was diagnosed with a urinary tract infection and was treated with oral trimethoprim/sulfamethoxazole. She appears pale. Her temperature is 38.8°C (101.8°F), pulse is 82/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 128/84 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 99%. Examination shows pale conjunctivae. Crackles are heard at the right lung base. Cardiac examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
12.6 g/dL


Leukocyte count
11,500/mm3



Platelet count
230,000/mm3



Serum



 Na+

137 mEq/L


 Cl-

104 mEq/L


 K+

3.9 mEq/L


 Urea nitrogen

16 mg/dL


 Glucose
89 mg/dL


 Creatinine
0.8 mg/dL


An x-ray of the chest shows an infiltrate at the right lung base. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Inpatient treatment with intravenous ceftriaxone and oral azithromycin
Inpatient treatment with intravenous cefepime and oral levofloxacin

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Clindamycin is used for bacterial infections involving anaerobes (e.g., Clostridium, Bacteroides), such as lung abscesses and aspiration pneumonia. Aspiration pneumonia occurs after foreign material is inhaled into the respiratory tract, often following manipulation of the respiratory or gastrointestinal tract (e.g., upper gastrointestinal endoscopy) or due to vomiting. Risk factors associated with aspiration pneumonia include heavy drinking, sedation, general anesthesia, apoplexy, and neurodegenerative conditions. In addition, patients typically present with foul-smelling sputum. This patient has none of these factors.

B) CORRECT:

Treatment with oral amoxicillin for community-acquired pneumonia is appropriate for patients with no preexisting comorbid conditions or risk factors for drug-resistant pathogens (e.g., recent antibiotic therapy, residence in a nursing home). Outpatient therapy is appropriate for patients with a CURB-65 score ≤ 1. This patient does not appear confused, has urea nitrogen < 20 mg/dL, a respiratory rate < 30/min, systolic blood pressure > 90 mm Hg, diastolic blood pressure > 60 mm Hg, and is under 65 years of age, amounting to a CURB-65 score of 0. Alternative first-line outpatient therapies include monotherapy with doxycycline or a macrolide such as azithromycin (in areas where macrolide-resistant S. pneumonia rates are < 25%).

Any patient being treated in a primary care setting should be reexamined after 48–72 hours to evaluate the efficacy of the prescribed antibiotic.

C) INCORRECT:

Inpatient treatment with a combination of ceftriaxone and azithromycin is indicated in patients with community-acquired pneumonia and a CURB-65 score ≥ 2. Although this patient likely has community-acquired pneumonia, she has a CURB-65 score of 0, which means that inpatient treatment with these antibiotics is not indicated.

D) INCORRECT:

Levofloxacin is often referred to as a respiratory fluoroquinolone because of its effectiveness in both typical and atypical pneumonia. Outpatient treatment with levofloxacin is used in patients with community-acquired pneumonia (CAP), a CURB-65 score ≤ 1, and additional risk factors for resistant pathogens such as the following: parenteral antibiotic therapy within the past 90 days; comorbidities (e.g., chronic cardiac, liver, or renal disease, diabetes mellitus, alcohol use disorder, malignancy); and residence in a nursing home. This patient received oral antibiotic treatment 6 months ago, which does not constitute a risk factor for resistant pathogens in CAP.

E) INCORRECT:

Inpatient treatment with intravenous cefepime and oral levofloxacin is indicated in patients with community-acquired pneumonia (CAP), a CURB-65 score ≥ 2, and increased risk for Pseudomonas aeruginosa pneumonia (e.g., immunosuppression, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, structural lung disease). Although this patient likely has CAP, she has a CURB-65 score of 0 and no risk factors for P. aeruginosa pneumonia. Therefore, inpatient treatment with these antibiotics is not indicated.

F) INCORRECT:

Outpatient treatment with ceftriaxone (solely) is not used to treat pneumonia. Inpatient treatment with a beta-lactam, such as ceftriaxone, in combination with a macrolide antibiotic or doxycycline can be used in patients with community-acquired pneumonia, a CURB-65 score ≤ 1, and without risk factors for MRSA and P. aeruginosa.
questions.hint: This patient has a productive cough, fever, and pleuritic chest pain, all of which suggest community-acquired pneumonia. Auscultation findings and x-ray findings support the diagnosis. She has a CURB-65 score of 0.

questions.text:
A 39-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a fever, nausea, and a nonproductive cough for 7 days. During this period, she has had headaches, generalized fatigue, and muscle and joint pain. She has also had increasing shortness of breath for 2 days. She has type 2 diabetes mellitus and osteoarthritis of her left knee. Current medications include insulin and ibuprofen. She had smoked two packs of cigarettes daily for 20 years but stopped 2 years ago. Her temperature is 38.1°C (100.6°F), pulse is 94/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 132/86 mm Hg. The lungs are clear to auscultation. There are multiple skin lesions with a blue livid center, pale intermediate zone, and a dark red peripheral rim on the upper and lower extremities. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
14.6 g/dL


Leukocyte count
11,100/mm3



Serum



 Na+

137 mEq/L


 K+

4.1 mEq/L


 Cl-

99 mEq/L


 Urea nitrogen
17 mg/dL


 Glucose
123 mg/dL


 Creatinine
0.9 mg/dL


An x-ray of the chest is shown. Which of the following is the most likely causal organism?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Klebsiella pneumoniae causes hospital-acquired pneumonia, aspiration pneumonia, or, less commonly, community-acquired typical pneumonia. K. pneumoniae most often affects older males, especially those with diabetes (which this patient does have), chronic lung disease, and/or alcohol use disorder. Although infection with K. pneumoniae may also manifest with fever and cough, the fever is usually high with shaking chills and the cough is productive with sputum that is generally thick and bloody (currant jelly). X-ray typically would show a consolidation in an upper lobe with air bronchograms and bulging of an adjacent interlobar fissure.
Image Description:

X-ray chest (PA and lateral views) of a patient with pneumonia

There is heterogeneous right upper lobe consolidation (green overlay) with air bronchograms (examples of bronchial walls indicated by white lines). The major (white dashed line) and minor fissures (red dashed lines) are elevated from normal position as a result of accompanying atelectasis. No hilar enlargement or pleural effusion is seen.

The differential diagnosis for airspace consolidation considers the radiographic appearance, associated findings (e.g., lymphadenopathy, pleural effusion), and patient history and symptoms. Pneumonia, hemorrhage, edema, tumor, and protein can all present as consolidation on a chest radiograph.

Green line: aortic arch margin; LL: lower lobe; ML: middle lobe; UL: upper lobe

B) INCORRECT:

Streptococcus pneumoniae is the most common cause of community-acquired typical pneumonia. Typical pneumonia is characterized by high fever, shaking chills, productive cough, decreased breath sounds and crackles on examination, and lobar consolidation on x-ray, none of which are present in this patient.
Image Description:

X-ray chest (lateral view)

Marked opacification of the left upper lobe (UL) is accompanied by volume loss; the major fissure (red line) is located anterior to its normal position (indicated by dashed line) and the left lower lobe (LL) is hyperinflated.

C) INCORRECT:

Haemophilus influenzae causes typical pneumonia, which, in contrast to the patients' symptoms, is characterized by high fever, shaking chills, productive cough, decreased breath sounds and crackles on examination, and lobar consolidation on x-ray. Furthermore, H. influenzae more commonly affects children.
Image Description:

X-ray chest (left: PA view; right: lateral view) of a patient with history of pneumonia

Extensive heterogeneous air space consolidation (green overlay) in the left upper lobe abuts part of the major fissure (dashed line). A small pleural effusion is present.

Examples of causes of pulmonary consolidation that can mimic the appearance of infectious pneumonia include organizing pneumonia, malignancy (adenocarcinoma, lymphoma), and pulmonary hemorrhage.

Red: meniscus of pleural effusion

D) INCORRECT:

Staphylococcus aureus is a common cause of hospital-acquired pneumonia and often develops as a superinfection in patients with influenza pneumonia. Although S. aureus pneumonia can be associated with interstitial or patchy infiltrates on chest x-ray, this diagnosis is unlikely because it usually occurs in older adults or individuals with immunodeficiency. Also, this patient does not have a history of recent hospital admission.

E) CORRECT:

Mycoplasma pneumoniae is one of the most frequent causes of atypical pneumonia, especially in the ambulatory setting and in patients younger than 40 years of age. Outbreaks of atypical pneumonia usually occur in crowded environments (e.g., schools, military barracks, hospitals, prisons) and often spread within households because the infection is transmitted via droplets. Since the lung infiltrates in patients with atypical pneumonia affect the interstitial space, the lungs typically sound clear on auscultation. Erythema multiforme is often associated with M. pneumoniae infection.

Antibiotics that disrupt intracellular processes (e.g., macrolides, tetracyclines, fluoroquinolones) are the preferred treatment for M. pneumoniae pneumonia, as M. pneumoniae lacks a cell wall and beta-lactam antibiotics (e.g., penicillin or cephalosporins) are therefore ineffective.

F) INCORRECT:

Legionella pneumophila can cause respiratory symptoms similar to those seen in this patient (Legionnaires' disease). This pathogen is common in smokers as well as patients with underlying chronic lung disease or recent exposure to contaminated water (air-conditioned hotels, cruise ships, hospitals). However, in contrast to other types of atypical pneumonia, patients characteristically have high fever (usually > 39°C or 102.2°F) and chills, often accompanied by diarrhea and confusion (due to hyponatremia), none of which is present in this patient. X-ray findings are variable but usually show patchy unilateral and lobar infiltrates that progress to consolidation rather than a diffuse interstitial infiltrate. Furthermore, Legionella pneumonia is not associated with erythema multiforme.
Image Description:

X-ray chest (PA view) of a patient with a history of Legionella pneumonia

An abnormal area of airspace opacification (green overlay) is seen medially in the left lung projecting over the hilum. The sharp edge along its inferolateral aspect (red line) may be a portion of a major fissure displaced by accompanying volume loss.
questions.hint: This patient's indolent course of low-grade fever, nonproductive cough, and clear lungs on physical examination in conjunction with her x-ray findings (i.e., linear and reticular infiltrates with confluent opacities in upper lobes) indicate atypical pneumonia. The concurrent skin rash (erythema multiforme) provides another clue as to the most likely pathogen.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of a cough, dyspnea, and fever for 1 day. The cough is productive of small amounts of green phlegm. He has metastatic colon cancer and has received three cycles of chemotherapy with 5-fluorouracil, leucovorin, and oxaliplatin; his last chemotherapy session was 2.5 months ago. He has chronic obstructive pulmonary disease and has been treated with antibiotics and prednisolone for acute exacerbations three times in the past year. His medications include a fluticasone-salmeterol inhaler and a tiotropium bromide inhaler. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 48 years. His temperature is 39.1°C (103.1°F), pulse is 112/min, respirations are 32/min, and blood pressure is 88/69 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 88%. Pulmonary examination shows diffuse crackles and rhonchi. An x-ray of the chest shows a left upper-lobe infiltrate of the lung. Two sets of blood cultures are obtained. Endotracheal aspirate Gram stain shows gram-negative rods. Two large-bore cannulas are inserted and intravenous fluids are administered. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Combination therapy with ceftriaxone and azithromycin is used to treat severe CAP that requires admission to the ICU (e.g., acute respiratory failure, septic shock). Although this patient has CAP and may require admission to the ICU, the most likely causative organism here is P. aeruginosa, against which ceftriaxone and azithromycin are not effective.

B) INCORRECT:

Ertapenem can be used to treat CAP caused by Streptococcus pneumoniae, Haemophilus influenzae, or Moraxella catarrhalis. Although this patient has CAP, ertapenem is ineffective against P. aeruginosa and is therefore not indicated in this case.

C) INCORRECT:

Vancomycin only provides coverage against gram-positive organisms and is mainly used to treat methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus. This patient most likely has an infection with P. aeruginosa, a gram-negative rod, against which vancomycin is ineffective.

D) INCORRECT:

Colistin is a last resort antibiotic that is used to treat multidrug-resistant gram-negative bacteria (MDRGN). Risk factors for MDRGN include prior antibiotic use, as seen in this patient, lengthy hospital stays, and age > 70 years. Although infection with a multidrug-resistant P. aeruginosa strain cannot be ruled out at this point, the patient should be started on the first-line empiric treatment for CAP with P. aeruginosa infection first. An antibiotic sensitivity test should be conducted before considering an antibiotic as a last resort.

E) CORRECT:

Cefepime and levofloxacin are the first-line treatment for patients with CAP in whom there is a high suspicion of P. aeruginosa infection. Other treatment options for CAP with P. aeruginosa include piperacillin/tazobactam, meropenem, or imipenem in combination with fluoroquinolone. An aminoglycoside may be added as well.

F) INCORRECT:

Clarithromycin and amoxicillin/clavulanate are used in the outpatient treatment of CAP patients with comorbidities and recent antibiotic treatment. This patient has chronic obstructive pulmonary disease and received recent antibiotic treatment, but he is not a candidate for outpatient treatment as he has a CURB-65 score ≥ 2 and is hypoxic. In addition, this regimen is not effective against P. aeruginosa and is therefore not appropriate in this patient.
questions.hint: The presence of fever, productive cough, crackles, and an infiltrate on the chest x-ray indicate community-acquired pneumonia (CAP). As this patient is hypoxic and has a CURB-65 score of 3 (respiratory rate ≥ 30/min, systolic blood pressure ≤ 90 mm Hg, age ≥ 65 years), he should be hospitalized. Given the patient's history of prior antibiotic treatments, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, possible immunosuppression due to chemotherapy, greenish sputum, and gram-negative rods on Gram stain, Pseudomonas aeruginosa is the most likely causal organism.

questions.text: Three days after undergoing an open cholecystectomy, a 57-year-old woman has fever, chills, and a headache. She has right-sided chest pain that increases on inspiration and has had a productive cough for the last 12 hours. She had an episode of hypotension after the operation that resolved with intravenous fluid therapy. She underwent an abdominal hysterectomy 16 years ago for multiple fibroids of the uterus. She has hypertension and psoriasis. Prior to being admitted to the hospital, her medications included amlodipine and clobetasol ointment. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 17 years. She appears uncomfortable. She is 165 cm (5 ft 5 in) tall and weighs 84 kg (185 lb); BMI is 31 kg/m2. Her temperature is 39°C (102.2°F), pulse is 98/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 128/82 mm Hg. Inspiratory crackles are heard at the right lung base. The abdomen is soft and nontender. There is a healing surgical incision below the right rib cage. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Left heart failure associated with congestive heart failure typically leads to pulmonary symptoms (e.g., dyspnea, orthopnea, cough), which may resemble those seen in this patient. However, this patient presenting with fever 3 days following surgery is more concerning for an alternative diagnosis.

B) INCORRECT:

One of the most important risk factors of pulmonary embolism (PE) is immobility (e.g., following surgery). Clinical presentation is variable, with symptoms including chest pain, coughing, dyspnea, tachycardia, and even obstructive shock. Although this patient presents with chest pain shortly after her surgery, and fever can also be present in PE, productive cough and crackles at the right lung base suggest a different diagnosis. She also has neither tachycardia nor a history of or current signs of deep vein thrombosis (e.g., swelling, tenderness, and/or discoloration of the lower extremities).

C) INCORRECT:

Subphrenic abscess may occur when pus accumulates between the spleen, diaphragm, and liver. Subphrenic abscess typically manifests with pain, nausea, vomiting, fever, and abdominal pain most commonly around 10 days after surgery. Although the patient has fever, it started 2 days after her operation and she has no other typical features of a subphrenic abscess.

D) CORRECT:

This patient's clinical presentation is most consistent with postoperative pneumonia, a common postsurgical complication that typically manifests 3 to 5 days following surgery. Additionally, this patient has undergone upper abdominal surgery and is a smoker, both of which are predisposing factors. Other known risk factors for postoperative pulmonary complications include thoracic surgery, surgery duration > 3–4 hours, patient age > 50 years, preexisting lung disease, and poor general health status.

E) INCORRECT:

Clinical features of atelectasis depend on the severity and extent of atelectasis and range from no symptoms to respiratory distress. Physical examination reveals dullness to percussion and diminished breathing sounds over the affected area. This patient has a productive cough, pleuritic chest pain, and inspiratory crackles, all of which make atelectasis less likely. The role of atelectasis in the postoperative development of fever is controversial; some studies have concluded that the association may be coincidental.
Image Description:

1. Obstructive atelectasis: foreign body aspiration results in airflow obstruction, poor ventilation, and atelectasis.

2. Non-obstructive atelectasis:
A) Compression atelectasis: A pleural effusion causes increased intrathoracic pressure actively forcing air out of the alveoli.
B) Relaxation atelectasis: A pneumothorax disrupts the contact between the visceral and parietal pleurae, resulting in passive atelectasis.
C) Cicatrization atelectasis: Generalized parenchymal fibrosis impairs full expansion of the right lung.
D) Adhesive atelectasis: Increased surface tension due to a deficiency of surfactant leads to generalized alveolar collapse.

F) INCORRECT:

Although this patient presents with pleuritic chest pain, she does not have tachycardia, diminished breath sounds, decreased chest excursion, or hyperresonant percussion, which would be expected with pneumothorax. She also presents with fever and productive cough, both of which are inconsistent with pneumothorax.
questions.hint: Fever, productive cough, pleuritic chest pain, and crackles are all common features of this postoperative complication, which typically occurs 3–5 days after surgery.

questions.text: An x-ray of the chest shows an extensive consolidation within the right lower lobe consistent with lobar pneumonia. Sputum and blood cultures are sent to the laboratory for analysis, and empiric antibiotic treatment with intravenous cefepime is begun. Which of the following is most likely to have prevented this patient's pneumonia?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Incentive spirometry and deep breathing exercises can maintain and improve lung function after surgery by keeping alveoli open, thereby decreasing the risk of atelectasis and pneumonia. Although some studies have shown a limited effect, these measures are still recommended following thoracic and upper abdominal surgery because they are safe and cost-effective. Multiple factors increase the postoperative risk of pneumonia, such as restricted thoracic and abdominal movement due to pain and intubation-related changes in ventilation (e.g., mechanical compression, impaired surfactant functioning). Further strategies to promote lung expansion include early mobilization and adequate postoperative pain control.

Preoperative measures to reduce pulmonary complications include smoking cessation (preferably ≥ 8 weeks before surgery), oral care (e.g., dental consult, improved oral hygiene), and treatment optimization for chronic lung diseases (e.g., asthma, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease).

B) INCORRECT:

Rapid sequence induction (RSI) is indicated in patients at high risk for pulmonary aspiration. While aspiration can cause pneumonia, this patient has no obvious risk factors for aspiration such as emergency surgery, severe GERD, anatomical defects of the gastrointestinal tract (e.g., hiatal hernia), or loss of protective airway reflexes.

C) INCORRECT:

Adequate breathing for this patient may be limited by postoperative pain following open abdominal surgery. Analgesics, including with opioids if needed, play an important role in ensuring sufficient breathing following such procedures to prevent postoperative atelectasis and/or pneumonia. A reduction in opioid consumption would not be indicated. Minimizing opioid administration would help prevent postoperative ileus, but this patient currently has no signs or symptoms of ileus.

D) INCORRECT:

For patients undergoing an open procedure, a single injection of antibiotics is usually administered directly before the procedure. Perioperative antibiotic prophylaxis reduces the incidence of postoperative surgical site infections. However, this single dose would not have prevented the development of postoperative pneumonia in this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

Good preoperative oral hygiene (e.g., brushing teeth twice daily, flossing daily, regular professional dental cleanings) reduces oral bacteria, lowering the risk of postoperative pneumonia. However, preoperative chlorhexidine mouthwash is only recommended for patients undergoing cardiac surgery.
questions.hint: Postoperative care should include measures to prevent postoperative pulmonary complications.

questions.text:
A 58-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of a 2-day history of increasing chest pain and shortness of breath. She has had a productive cough with foul-smelling sputum for 1 week. Seven months ago, the patient had an ischemic stroke. She has gastritis and untreated hypertension. She currently lives in an assisted living community. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 40 years. She has a 20-year history of alcohol use disorder but has not consumed any alcohol in the past 4 years. Her only medication is omeprazole. She appears to be in respiratory distress and speaks incoherently. Her temperature is 39.3°C (102.7°F), pulse is 123/min, respirations are 33/min, and blood pressure is 155/94 mm Hg. Auscultation of the lung shows rales and decreased breath sounds over the right upper lung field. Examination shows weakness and decreased sensation of the right upper and lower extremities. Babinski sign and facial drooping are present on the right. Arterial blood gas analysis on room air shows:


pH
7.48


PCO2

31 mm Hg


PO2

58 mm Hg


O2 saturation
74%


A chest x-ray shows infiltrates in the posterior segment of the right upper lobe. Which of the following is the strongest risk factor for this patient's respiratory symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Living in an assisted living community is a risk factor for pneumonia because of the advanced age and reduced functional status of the inhabitants, as well as exposure to other sick contacts within the community. However, living in an assisted living community does not increase the risk of aspiration pneumonia specifically, and this patient has a more significant risk factor that should be considered.

B) INCORRECT:

Smoking is a risk factor for stroke and cardiovascular diseases, which can affect pneumonia outcomes. Additionally, smoking can lead to chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, which can increase the risk of aspiration. However, smoking history alone is not a risk factor for aspiration pneumonia.

C) INCORRECT:

A history of alcohol use disorder increases the risk for many conditions, including hepatic dysfunction and cerebral atrophy. Although acute alcohol intoxication can lead to temporarily reduced reflexes and aspiration, past alcohol use disorder is not a risk factor for aspiration pneumonia.

D) INCORRECT:

Untreated hypertension is a risk factor for stroke and cardiovascular diseases, which can affect pneumonia outcomes. However, untreated hypertension alone is not a risk factor for pneumonia.

E) CORRECT:

Ischemic stroke is a risk factor for aspiration pneumonia because it can impair the mechanisms for swallowing and coughing. Patients with a history of stroke should be evaluated by a specialist, and dietary modifications should be made when necessary based on their level of dysphagia. In patients who aspirate while supine, the most common sites of pneumonia are the superior segment of the right lower lobe and the posterior segment of the right upper lobe.

F) INCORRECT:

Gastrointestinal reflux disease can cause aspiration pneumonia due to the risk of aspirating refluxed gastric contents. However, gastritis is not associated with reflux and is not a risk factor for aspiration pneumonia. Although this condition is treated with proton pump inhibitors, which may increase the risk of aspiration pneumonia, this patient has a more significant risk factor that should be considered.
questions.hint: This patient's fever, dyspnea, productive cough with foul-smelling sputum, hypoxemia, and infiltrates in the posterior segment of the right upper lobe suggest aspiration pneumonia.

questions.text: A 59-year-old woman comes to the physician because of increasing shortness of breath, malaise, and a cough for the past week. The cough is productive of a small volume of green sputum. Over the past 9 months, she was hospitalized twice for left lower lobe pneumonia. Her medical history is otherwise unremarkable. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 36 years. Her temperature is 39.3°C (102.7°F), pulse is 103/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 132/84 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 89%. Auscultation of the lungs discloses end-expiratory wheezes, and decreased breath sounds and crackles are heard at the left lung base. Cardiac examination shows no abnormalities. Chest x-ray shows a homogeneous area of increased opacification in the left lower lobe. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in diagnosis?

choices.text: HIV antigen and anti-HIV antibody testing

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Interferon-gamma release assay (IGRA) is a diagnostic test for tuberculosis (TB), which can manifest with fever, productive cough, dyspnea, and pulmonary infiltrates. Lower lobe consolidations may be seen in active primary TB or as a sequela thereof (Ghon complex); however, this patient lacks many other signs of active TB (e.g., weight loss, night sweats, hemoptysis) and has no history of immunosuppression or risk factors for TB (e.g., HIV infection, travel to endemic country). A positive IGRA may indicate active TB but is more commonly used to diagnose latent TB, which is typically asymptomatic. Although latent TB can reactivate, secondary TB usually affects the upper rather than lower lobes.

B) INCORRECT:

Bronchoscopy is indicated to detect and biopsy endobronchial lesions and malignancies, which can cause obstruction and lead to recurrent pneumonia. Additionally, bronchoscopy with bronchoalveolar lavage may be useful in persistent pneumonia that is resistant to treatment to obtain bronchial samples for culture and cytology. However, bronchoscopy is an invasive procedure, and the location of the lesion and corresponding anatomy should be determined before pursuing this test.

C) INCORRECT:

Upper endoscopy is used to evaluate esophageal conditions in patients with recurrent pneumonia due to aspiration. Esophageal conditions associated with aspiration include esophageal diverticula, gastroesophageal reflux disease, and esophageal motility disorders; this patient has no findings suggestive of these conditions (e.g., dysphagia, regurgitation, retrosternal pain). Moreover, aspiration pneumonia is more common in the right lung than the left lung because of the steep angle of the right bronchus.

D) INCORRECT:

Combined antigen and antibody tests for HIV have a sensitivity of almost 100% and are the tests of choice to screen for HIV. Patients with HIV are susceptible to Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia, Mycobacterium avium complex infection, and coccidioidomycosis, all of which can manifest with symptoms of recurrent pneumonia. While this patient's recurrent pneumonia should raise suspicion for an underlying cause, the recurrence in the same anatomical region points to an etiology other than immunodeficiency.

E) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary function tests (PFTs) are used to diagnose chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, which is likely in a patient with a long history of smoking and end-expiratory wheezes on physical examination. However, this patient currently has pneumonia, which necessitates a different diagnostic step. PFTs are also used for preoperative assessment of patients with planned lung resection and/or suspected respiratory disease. Although this patient's condition has likely developed due to lung cancer, which she may require lung surgery for at a later time, the diagnosis first needs to be confirmed.

F) CORRECT:

A CT scan of the chest is the most appropriate diagnostic step for a case of nonresolving pneumonia in the same anatomic region. This imaging test has a higher sensitivity for mass lesions than a chest x-ray and provides an accurate anatomic location of the mass for further diagnostic or treatment procedures, such as biopsy and/or surgery. If there is a pulmonary mass with signs of malignancy on chest CT (e.g., solid lesion ≥ 8 mm, with irregular margins, spiculated), the next step in management is to perform a CT-guided biopsy (if the mass is peripheral) or a bronchoscopy (if the mass is centrally located).

Patients with recurrent pneumonia in different anatomic regions, especially if concurrent with other infections (e.g., sinusitis), should be evaluated for an underlying systemic condition and/or immunodeficiency (e.g., granulomatosis with polyangiitis, multiple myeloma, HIV infection).
Image Description:

Click on the overlay icon below the taskbar on the left to toggle the overlay on and off.

CT chest (with contrast; axial plane, mediastinal window; axial plane, lung window) of a patient with symptoms of pneumonia

Dense consolidation nearly completely opacifies the left lower lobe. Some areas of relative sparing are seen, especially within the superior segment. Reactive lymph nodes are present along the left superior mediastinum and central pulmonary vessels. There is a very small left pleural effusion .
questions.hint: This patient's findings indicate left lower lobe pneumonia. Recurrent pneumonia in the same location suggests obstruction due to an anatomic abnormality or pulmonary mass. In patients with a long history of smoking, recurrent pneumonia raises suspicion for lung cancer.

questions.text: Twelve hours after admission to the hospital because of a high-grade fever for 3 days, a 15-year-old boy has shortness of breath. During this period, he has had generalized malaise and a cough productive of moderate amounts of green sputum. For the past 10 days, he has had fever, a sore throat, and muscle aches; these symptoms initially improved, but worsened again over the past 5 days. His temperature is 38.7°C (101.7°F), pulse is 109/min, respirations are 27/min, and blood pressure is 100/70 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 93%. There are decreased breath sounds and crackles heard over the right upper lung field. His hemoglobin concentration is 13.3 g/dL, leukocyte count is 15,000/mm3, and platelet count is 289,000/mm3. An x-ray of the chest shows a right upper-lobe infiltrate. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Klebsiella species are a common cause of hospital-acquired pneumonia (HAP), and community-acquired pneumonia in patients with alcohol use disorder. HAP can only be diagnosed if pneumonia develops > 48 hours after the patient is admitted to the hospital. Klebsiella species cause pneumonia that is classically associated with currant jelly sputum and Klebsiella species are not a common cause of postviral bacterial pneumonia.

B) CORRECT:

The most common causes of postviral bacterial pneumonia are Streptococcus pneumoniae, Staphylococcus aureus, and Haemophilus influenzae. Bacterial superinfection should be suspected in any patient presenting with exacerbation of fever and severe respiratory symptoms after initial improvement of flu symptoms. The influenza virus causes a dysfunction of the tracheobronchial epithelium, which makes affected patients more susceptible to secondary infection with bacteria. Post-influenza pneumonia should be treated empirically with antibiotics until culture results are available.

C) INCORRECT:

Mycoplasma pneumoniae is a common cause of atypical pneumonia. In contrast with this patient's findings, atypical pneumonia typically manifests with a dry rather than a productive cough and has an indolent course; pulmonary auscultation is often unremarkable. Mycoplasma pneumoniae is also not a common cause of postviral bacterial pneumonia.

D) INCORRECT:

Staphylococcus epidermidis is responsible for device-related infections, which can occur in patients with intravenous catheters, heart valves, or orthopedic implants. S. epidermidis is not a common cause of bacterial pneumonia. A different Staphylococcus species is a common cause of postviral bacterial pneumonia.

E) INCORRECT:

Chlamydophila pneumoniae is a common cause of atypical pneumonia. In contrast with this patient's findings, atypical pneumonia typically manifests with a dry rather than a productive cough and has an indolent course; pulmonary auscultation is often unremarkable. Chlamydophila pneumoniae is also not a common cause of postviral bacterial pneumonia.

F) INCORRECT:

Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a common cause of hospital-acquired pneumonia (HAP), and community-acquired pneumonia in patients with underlying chronic lung disease (e.g., COPD, bronchiectasis). This patient does not have chronic lung disease and HAP can only be diagnosed if pneumonia develops > 48 hours after the patient is admitted to the hospital. P. aeruginosa is not a common cause of postviral bacterial pneumonia.

G) INCORRECT:

Legionella pneumophila can cause pneumonia but also typically manifests with gastrointestinal symptoms (e.g., nausea, vomiting, diarrhea) and neurological features (e.g., altered mental status), which are not seen here. Moreover, L. pneumophila is not a common cause of postviral bacterial pneumonia. L. pneumophila infection is contracted by inhaling contaminated aerosols, which can happen in confined spaces like cruise ships, hotels, resorts, or nursing homes.
questions.hint: This patient initially had features of influenza (malaise, fever, sore throat, muscle ache) and now presents with features of bacterial pneumonia (productive cough, infiltrate on chest x-ray). Postviral bacterial pneumonia is often caused by specific pathogens.

questions.text: A 67-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department for the evaluation of fever, chest pain, and a cough productive of a moderate amount of greenish-yellow sputum for 2 days. During this period, she has had severe malaise, chills, and difficulty breathing. She has hypertension, hypercholesterolemia, and type 2 diabetes mellitus. She smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 20 years, but quit 5 years ago. Current medications include simvastatin, captopril, and metformin. Temperature is 39°C (102.2°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 33/min, and blood pressure is 143/88 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 94%. Crackles are heard on auscultation over the right upper lung field. Laboratory studies show a leukocyte count of 12,300/mm3, an erythrocyte sedimentation rate of 60 mm/h, and a urea nitrogen of 15 mg/dL. A chest x-ray is shown. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management?

choices.text: Inpatient treatment with cefepime, azithromycin, and gentamicin
ICU admission and administration of ceftriaxone and azithromycin
Outpatient treatment with azithromycin and amoxicillin/clavulanate
Inpatient treatment with azithromycin and cefotaxime
ICU admission and administration of ampicillin/sulbactam and levofloxacin
ICU admission and administration of aztreonam and levofloxacin

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Outpatient treatment with moxifloxacin is recommended for the treatment of community-acquired pneumonia in individuals with risk factors such as recent antibiotic treatment, preexisting neurological conditions, diseases of internal organs, or living in nursing homes, and a CURB-65 score ≤ 1. This patient has a CURB-65 score of 2.

B) INCORRECT:

This patient's CURB-65 score of 2 necessitates hospitalization. Cefepime is usually used for nosocomial infections with pathogens such as Pseudomonas aeruginosa, Staphylococcus aureus, and Streptococcus pneumoniae. Azithromycin is effective against S. pneumoniae and atypical organisms. Gentamicin is effective against gram-negative bacteria (e.g., P. aeruginosa). They are used in combination to treat pneumonia when P. aeruginosa is suspected. This patient has no risk factors for P. aeruginosa infection such as immunosuppression, long hospital stay, ventilation > 3 days, and structural lung disease, and therefore, a different therapy regimen is indicated.

C) INCORRECT:

ICU admission is indicated in patients with severe respiratory failure, septic shock, or decompensation of other systemic illnesses like chronic renal or cardiac disease. While the combination of ceftriaxone and azithromycin may be considered for this patient's pneumonia, she does not present with features that would warrant ICU admission.

D) INCORRECT:

Outpatient treatment with azithromycin, amoxicillin, and clavulanate is recommended for the treatment of community-acquired pneumonia in individuals with a CURB-65 score ≤ 1 in addition to risk factors such as recent antibiotic treatment, preexisting neurological conditions, diseases of internal organs, or living in nursing homes. However, this woman's CURB-65 score is 2, which warrants more urgent treatment than that provided with outpatient care.

E) CORRECT:

Inpatient treatment with a combination of a macrolide and an antipneumococcal beta-lactam (e.g., azithromycin and cefotaxime) is indicated in patients with community-acquired pneumonia and a CURB-65 score ≥ 2. Hospital admission and administration of a respiratory fluoroquinolone (e.g., levofloxacin) would also be an appropriate treatment in this case. Since this patient has no further complications or risk factors such as acute respiratory failure, septic shock, or decompensation of comorbidities, ICU management is not necessary at this point.

F) INCORRECT:

ICU admission is indicated in patients with severe respiratory failure, septic shock, or decompensation of other systemic illnesses like chronic renal or cardiac diseases. The combination of ampicillin/sulbactam and levofloxacin is used to treat ICU patients with pneumonia in whom Pseudomonas is not suspected. This patient does not present with features that would warrant ICU admission or this antibiotic treatment.

G) INCORRECT:

Outpatient treatment with azithromycin alone is only recommended for the treatment of community-acquired pneumonia in patients with a CURB-65 score ≤ 1. This patient has a CURB-65 score of 2.

H) INCORRECT:

Hospital admission is indicated in this patient because her CURB-65 score is 2, but another therapy regimen is needed. Ceftriaxone is effective against pneumococci, meningococci, and certain gram-negative rods. However, it does not cover atypical organisms like Mycoplasma or Chlamydia, which require additional empirical treatment.

I) INCORRECT:

ICU admission is indicated in patients with severe respiratory failure, septic shock, or decompensation of other systemic illness like chronic cardiac and renal diseases. The combination of aztreonam and levofloxacin is used to treat ICU patients with pneumonia who are allergic to penicillin and in whom Pseudomonas is not suspected. This patient does not present with features that would warrant ICU admission or this antibiotic treatment.
questions.hint: This patient presents with fever, productive cough, malaise, chills, dyspnea, and extensive opacity restricted to the upper lobe of the right lung on chest x-ray. Together, these features suggest community-acquired pneumonia. Moreover, her CURB-65 score is ≥ 2 (she is 67 years old and her respiration rate is 33/min).

questions.text: An 80-year-old man is brought to the emergency department from a nursing home because of a 2-day history of increasing cough, fever, and dyspnea. He has type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension. Current medications include insulin and enalapril. On arrival, he has dyspnea and is disoriented to person, place, and time. His temperature is 38.1°C (100.6°F), pulse is 113/min, respirations are 35/min, and blood pressure is 78/60 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 77%. Auscultation shows diffuse crackles over the right lung field. Cardiac examination shows an S4 gallop. Intravenous fluid resuscitation is begun. He is intubated, mechanically ventilated, and moved to the intensive care unit. An x-ray of the chest shows right upper and middle lobe infiltrates and an enlarged cardiac silhouette. A norepinephrine infusion is begun and the patient is administered intravenous antibiotics. Which of the following would most likely be found on Gram stain examination of this patient's sputum?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Gram-negative coccobacilli are classic Gram stain findings for Haemophilus influenzae, which is a common cause of community-acquired pneumonia. However, it is not the most commonly identified bacterial pathogen.

B) INCORRECT:

No findings on Gram stain could occur in atypical pneumonia from Mycoplasma pneumoniae or Chlamydophila pneumoniae. Atypical pneumonia develops insidiously and is usually milder than typical pneumonia. Some patients are asymptomatic, while others experience low fever, headache, malaise, dry cough, or other extrapulmonary symptoms. This patient has typical pneumonia based on symptoms of cough, fever, and dyspnea, which are severe enough to require hospitalization.

C) INCORRECT:

Gram-positive cocci in clusters are classic Gram stain findings for Staphylococcus aureus, which can cause postinfluenza pneumonia through bacterial superinfection. There is no mention of this patient having had the flu with high fever, chills, severe malaise, or joint and muscle pain days to weeks prior to developing pneumonia. S. aureus is not the most common cause of pneumonia in residents of long-term care facilities.

D) CORRECT:

Gram-positive diplococci are classic Gram stain findings for Streptococcus pneumoniae, which is the most common cause of pneumonia among residents of long-term care facilities. S. pneumonia is also the most common cause of community-acquired pneumonia across all age groups.
Image Description:

Scanning electron photomicrograph

A joined pair of spherical cocci (diplococci) is visible.

E) INCORRECT:

Gram-negative rods on Gram stain could indicate Enterobacteriaceae, such as Escherichia coli, Klebsiella pneumoniae, or Pseudomonas aeruginosa, which can also cause typical pneumonia. Pneumonia due to E. coli is mainly seen in neonates or patients with aspiration pneumonia. P. aeruginosa may cause ventilator-associated pneumonia and is especially common in patients with cystic fibrosis. K. pneumonia is a common cause of nosocomial infections in immunocompromised patients. This patient, however, does not have any risk factors for aspiration, e.g., neurocognitive decline, dysphagia, psychoactive polypharmacy, or substance misuse. In addition, there is no history of prolonged intubation prior to admission, cystic fibrosis, or immunocompromise. Furthermore, another organism is most commonly responsible for pneumonia among residents of long-term care facilities.

F) INCORRECT:

Gram-positive branching bacteria are classic Gram stain findings for Nocardia. Pulmonary nocardiosis is most commonly seen in patients with obstructions, pulmonary neoplasms, granulomatosis with polyangiitis, or immunodeficiency. This unusual organism may cause recurrent pneumonia, but this patient has no history thereof. Nocardia is not the most common cause of pneumonia in residents of long-term care facilities.
questions.hint: This 80-year-old man has fever, dyspnea, cough, and a chest x-ray showing infiltrates, all of which indicate pneumonia. The most common causal pathogen of pneumonia in residents of long-term care facilities is the same as the organism most commonly responsible for community-acquired pneumonia.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of a 2-day history of weakness. She has also noticed that her urine is darker than usual. For the past week, she has had a persistent nonproductive cough and low-grade fever. She has seasonal allergies. She does not smoke and drinks one to two glasses of wine on social occasions. Her temperature is 37.9°C (100.2°F), pulse is 88/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 110/76 mm Hg. She has conjunctival pallor and scleral icterus. Cardiopulmonary examination shows bibasilar crackles. The remainder of the physical examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
7.1 g/dL


Hematocrit
21%


Mean corpuscular volume
94 μm3



Leukocyte count
8000/mm3



Platelet count
210,000/mm3



Serum



 AST
15 U/L


 ALT
17 U/L


 Bilirubin, total

4.3 mg/dL


 Direct
1.1 mg/dL


 Lactate dehydrogenase

1251 U/L


 Haptoglobin


5.8 mg/dL (N = 41–165)


An x-ray of the chest shows bilateral patchy infiltrates. A peripheral blood smear shows spherocytes. Which of the following is most likely to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The ristocetin cofactor assay is used to help diagnose von Willebrand disease (vWD). In vWD, platelet adhesion is impaired, which results in ineffective primary hemostasis that can cause bleeding (e.g., epistaxis, menorrhagia), but the condition is usually asymptomatic. Regardless, vWD does not cause hemolytic anemia.

B) INCORRECT:

An osmotic fragility test is used to test for hereditary spherocytosis, which does cause hemolytic anemia and spherocytes but generally manifests already during infancy or early childhood, typically with a positive family history. Additionally, patients with hereditary spherocytosis typically also have splenomegaly (due to increased RBC breakdown) and often a history of cholelithiasis (due to pigment stones caused by elevated bilirubin from increased RBC breakdown).

C) CORRECT:

The direct Coombs test (direct antiglobulin test) detects antibodies bound to the RBC membrane and is the best confirmatory test in patients with AIHA. CAS, which is the most likely diagnosis in this patient, is a rare form of cold AIHA that develops secondary to another condition (e.g., infection). Cold AIHA is characterized by the presence of cold agglutinins (mostly cold-sensitive IgM antibodies). In contrast, warm AIHA is characterized by the presence of warm agglutinins (mostly heat-sensitive polyclonal IgG antibodies). Although the presence of multiple spherocytes on peripheral blood smear is more characteristic of warm AIHA (due to partial phagocytosis of the RBCs by splenic macrophages), patients with cold AIHA may also have spherocytes on peripheral blood smear. Low C3 and C4 serum concentrations (due to complement factor consumption) also support the diagnosis of cold AIHA.

A negative direct Coombs test indicates the absence of antibodies against RBCs and is consistent with a nonautoimmune cause of hemolytic anemia (e.g., enzyme deficiencies, hemoglobinopathies, mechanical destruction), which requires further workup.
Image Description:

A test used to detect hemolytic antibodies bound to RBCs (direct Coombs test) or freely circulating in the serum (indirect Coombs test).

1. The direct Coombs test is used to detect hemolytic antibodies or complement bound to the surface of a patient's erythrocytes. It is used to differentiate between autoimmune and nonimmune hemolytic anemias and to diagnose hemolytic diseases of the fetus and newborn.

2. The indirect Coombs test is used to detect hemolytic anti-RBC IgG antibodies (against foreign RBC antigens) present in a patient's serum. It is used to screen for maternal anti-D IgG antibodies (detection of hemolytic disease of the newborn) and to crossmatch blood before transfusions.

D) INCORRECT:

A deficiency of ADAMTS13 is the cause of thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP), which is characterized by the pentad of low platelet count, microangiopathic hemolytic anemia, fever, kidney dysfunction, and neurologic symptoms. While this patient has some features of hemolytic anemia, she does not have thrombocytopenia or neurologic symptoms such as hallucinations or delirium. This patient also does not display the characteristic features of microangiopathic hemolytic anemia, such as schistocytes on the blood smear and evidence of end-organ dysfunction (e.g., liver enzyme abnormalities). Moreover, petechiae, purpura, and other bleeding manifestations that are commonly seen in TTP are also absent.

E) INCORRECT:

Hemoglobin electrophoresis is used to confirm diagnoses like sickle cell anemia and thalassemias. Although sickle cell anemia does cause jaundice in a hemolytic crisis, it typically already presents in childhood. Additionally, this patient does not have a previous history of sickle crises (joint pains, dactylitis, acute chest syndrome) or any family history of sickle cell anemia that would raise suspicion of sickle cell disease. Similarly, thalassemia subtypes that would present with symptoms (thalassemia intermedia and major) would present earlier in life as chronic anemia.

F) INCORRECT:

Flow cytometry is useful to measure levels of CD55 and CD59 expression on the patient's peripheral blood cells in order to diagnose paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH). Although PNH cannot be completely ruled out in this patient, the onset of hemolytic anemia after a recent lower respiratory tract infection makes another diagnosis more likely.

G) INCORRECT:

Pyruvate kinase deficiency (PKD) is an RBC enzyme defect leading to shortened RBC lifespans and also causes hemolytic anemia. However, PKD usually causes symptoms already during early childhood, and patients typically have splenomegaly and a history of blood transfusions and newborn icterus.
questions.hint: Recent history of a nonproductive cough, low-grade fever, and a chest x-ray with bilateral patchy infiltrates suggests atypical pneumonia, likely due to infection with Mycoplasma pneumoniae. The presence of hemolytic anemia (jaundice, dark urine, low hemoglobin, indirect hyperbilirubinemia, high LDH, and low haptoglobin) in a patient with Mycoplasma pneumoniae infection should raise concern for autoimmune hemolytic anemia (AIHA), most likely due to cold agglutinin syndrome (CAS).

questions.text:
A 62-year-old man is brought to the emergency department with a 2-day history of cough productive of yellowish sputum. He has had fever, chills, and worsening shortness of breath during this time. He has a 10-year history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia. He does not drink alcohol or smoke cigarettes. His current medications include atorvastatin, amlodipine, and metoprolol. His temperature is 38.9°C (102.0°F), pulse is 105/min, respirations are 27/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. He appears in mild distress. He has rales over the left lower lung field. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Leukocyte count is 15,000/mm3 (87% segmented neutrophils). Arterial blood gas analysis on room air shows:


pH
7.44


pO2

68 mm Hg


pCO2

28 mm Hg


HCO3-

24 mEq/L


O2 saturation
91%


An x-ray of the chest shows a consolidation in the left lower lobe. Asking the patient to lie down in the left lateral decubitus position would most likely result in which of the following?

choices.text: Decreased ventilation of the left lung

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

In the lateral decubitus position, the dependent lung is better perfused due to the effect of gravity. Putting this patient in the left lateral decubitus position will therefore increase the perfusion of the left, diseased lung, not of the right, healthy lung.

B) INCORRECT:

The perfusion of the nonventilated, consolidated alveoli in pneumonia causes a decreased ventilation-perfusion ratio that results in hypoxemia. Placing the patient in the left decubitus position would actually worsen hypoxemia as more blood passes through the nonventilated portion of the lung and less blood passes through the right, healthy lung. Additionally, the healthy lung will be ventilated less, further contributing to a worsening of hypoxemia.

C) INCORRECT:

This patient's arterial blood gas analysis shows hypocapnia, as evidenced by the pCO2 of 28 mm Hg (normal pCO2: 33–45 mm Hg). In general, the dependent lung is better ventilated and perfused than the nondependent lung. Placing this patient with left lobar pneumonia in the left lateral decubitus position will increase ventilation and perfusion of the diseased lung. As there is no CO2 and O2 exchange at the sites of alveolar consolidation, there will be more CO2 retention, resulting in an improvement of the hypocapnia (but a worsening of the hypoxia) in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

Dependent portions of a healthy lung are better ventilated than the nondependent portions. This patient with pneumonia affecting the left lower lobe has consolidation on x-ray, which indicates the presence of fluid in the alveoli that prevents them from participating in ventilation. However, putting this patient in the left lateral decubitus position will still result in increased ventilation of the unaffected upper lobe of the diseased lung.

E) CORRECT:

The alveolar-arterial gradient (A-a gradient) is the difference between the partial pressure of O2 within the alveoli and that within the arterial blood. An increased A-a gradient indicates a ventilation/perfusion mismatch (V/Q mismatch) resulting in hypoxia. In pneumonia, ventilation decreases in the consolidated region of the lung due to alveolar inflammation (↓ V). In a lateral decubitus position, the dependent lung is better perfused (↑ Q) and ventilated than the nondependent regions. Placing this patient with left-sided pneumonia in the left lateral decubitus position will increase perfusion of the nonventilated alveoli, worsening the V/Q mismatch and increasing the A-a gradient.

Therefore, in patients with unilateral pneumonia with hypoxia, positioning the body with the healthy lung in the dependent position (“good lung down”) improves arterial oxygenation by increasing both its ventilation and perfusion.
questions.hint: This patient presents with clinical features of pneumonia, which impairs ventilation in the affected pulmonary tissue. The dependent regions of the lung are better perfused than the nondependent regions as gravity pulls the blood downward.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of a cough and poor appetite for the past week. During the same period, he has been coughing up small amounts of malodorous phlegm. During the past two nights, he has also had night sweats. He was diagnosed with HIV infection 5 years ago. He has hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and severe heartburn. The patient is homeless and does not take any medication. He has smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for 30 years. He drinks 8–10 beers daily. His temperature is 38.9°C (102.0°F), pulse is 101/min, respirations are 25/min, and blood pressure is 145/92 mm Hg. The patient appears intoxicated. Physical examination shows crackles and dullness to percussion at the right lung base. Scattered expiratory wheezing is heard throughout both lung fields. A grade 2/6 midsystolic ejection murmur is heard along the upper right sternal border. His CD4+ T-lymphocyte count is 280/mm3. An x-ray of the chest shows a hazy infiltrate in the right lower lung field. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Bronchoalveolar carcinoma (adenocarcinoma in situ) is a noninvasive type of lung cancer with a particular growth pattern referred to as lepidic. Early in the disease, chest x-ray findings include a solitary peripheral nodule, but in more advanced stages it presents as diffuse consolidation, whereas this patient x-ray shows a hazy infiltrate localized to the right lower lobe. Furthermore, this patient's acute presentation, fever, and lack of systemic symptoms of lung cancer (weight loss, hemoptysis, and fatigue), make a different diagnosis more likely.

B) INCORRECT:

Pneumocystis pneumonia (PCP) is a common opportunistic infection in patients with HIV and the most common cause of death in patients with AIDS. However, PCP manifests with a dry cough, diffuse bilateral dry crackles, and interstitial pneumonia on chest x-ray, unlike this patient's findings. Additionally, a CD4+ count > 200 cells/mm3 makes this diagnosis less likely.

C) CORRECT:

Cough, malodorous phlegm, and fever in the setting of alcohol use disorder and reflux (history of severe heartburn) are suggestive of aspiration pneumonia. This patient's chest x-ray showing a hazy infiltrate in the right lower lung field further supports this diagnosis. Altered consciousness is a risk factor for aspiration and is classically seen in alcohol use disorder, sedation, general anesthesia, and seizures. This patient's history of gastric reflux is an additional risk factor for aspiration, as it indicates lower esophageal sphincter dysfunction, which can lead to the regurgitation of gastric contents into the esophagus.

Further risk factors for aspiration include neurodegenerative conditions associated with reduced gag reflex and dysphagia, such as stroke, Parkinson disease, dementia, amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, or myasthenia gravis.

D) INCORRECT:

Bronchiectasis is mainly seen in patients with cystic fibrosis and/or recurrent pulmonary infections. This condition is characterized by copious amounts of mucopurulent sputum, unlike this patient's small amounts of malodorous phlegm. Furthermore, as opposed to this patient's hazy infiltrate in the right lower lobe, x-ray in bronchiectasis typically shows "tram track" lines due to chronic inflammation and fibrosis of the bronchial walls, which can progress to honeycombing.

E) INCORRECT:

Tuberculosis (TB) can manifest with cough, fever, night sweats, and poor appetite. Moreover, this patient's homelessness and history of alcohol use disorder and HIV with a CD4+ count < 400 cells/mm3 are risk factors for developing TB. While x-ray in primary TB can show consolidations in the middle and/or lower lobes, calcified nodules (Ghon complex) and cavitary lesions are also often present. The hazy infiltrate seen on x-ray in this patient is typical for another condition. Similarly, his recent-onset cough with malodorous phlegm is more suggestive of a different diagnosis.
Image Description:

Active pulmonary tuberculosis (TB) typically manifests with systemic (e.g., low-grade fever, night sweats, weight loss, decreased appetite, and malaise) and pulmonary symptoms (e.g., dyspnea, pleuritic chest pain due to pleural effusion, productive cough, and possibly hemoptysis in advanced stages).
Symptomatic TB can occur as a result of primary infection (primary active TB) or reactivation of latent infection (reactivation TB). While symptoms are similar in both conditions, radiographic presentation differs.
Radiographic imaging in primary TB commonly shows a Ghon complex (Ghon focus with its associated lymph node), unilateral hilar lymphadenopathy, and homogenous consolidation with ill-defined borders in the middle and lower lobes. Chest x-ray in reactivation TB typically shows multiple cavities in the upper lobes, calcifications, patchy consolidations, and features fibroproliferative disease (e.g, scarring) due to inflammatory tissue destruction.

F) INCORRECT:

Mitral valve regurgitation causes a pansystolic murmur best heard at the apex and can manifest with pulmonary edema, which can be heard on auscultation as bilateral crackles. However, this patient's 2/6 midsystolic ejection murmur best heard along the upper right sternal border is likely to be due to aortic stenosis. This patient's features (e.g., fever, cough, crackles localized to the right lower lobe) in conjunction with the x-ray findings suggest a different condition.

G) INCORRECT:

Pharyngoesophageal diverticulum (Zenker diverticulum) presents with foul-smelling regurgitation of undigested food. Although this patient has a cough productive of malodorous phlegm, he does not complain of food regurgitation. Patients with pharyngoesophageal diverticulum usually complain of dysphagia and a sensation of having a lump in their throat, which is not present in this patient. Moreover, fever and fatigue are not explained by a pharyngoesophageal diverticulum alone.
questions.hint: This patient's findings should raise concern for a condition caused by decreased gag reflex and altered consciousness.

questions.text: A 51-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 4-day history of fever and cough productive of foul-smelling, dark red, gelatinous sputum. He has smoked 1 pack of cigarettes daily for 30 years and drinks two 12-oz bottles of beer daily. An x-ray of the chest shows a cavity with air-fluid levels in the right lower lobe. Sputum culture grows gram-negative rods. Which of the following virulence factors is most likely involved in the pathogenesis of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Exotoxin A is produced by Pseudomonas aeruginosa, a gram-negative rod that can cause a lung abscess secondary to pneumonia, especially in patients with alcohol use disorder. However, lung infection by P. aeruginosa is typically associated with green-colored sputum, not dark red sputum, due to the production of pyocyanin.

B) INCORRECT:

IgA protease is secreted by Haemophilus influenzae (a gram-negative rod) and Streptococcus pneumoniae, both of which can cause a lung abscess secondary to pneumonia. However, Haemophilus influenzae infection is rarely seen in developed countries since introduction of the Hib vaccination, and Streptococcus pneumoniae is a gram-positive coccus.

C) INCORRECT:

Heat-stable toxins, such as the enterotoxins produced by Staphylococcus aureus, target the intestinal mucosa and cause food poisoning with enteritis. Although S. aureus can cause lung abscesses, heat-stable toxins are not responsible for the pathogenesis of pulmonary infections. Instead, other virulence factors, such as protein A, are involved in the pathogenesis of S. aureus pneumonia. Moreover, S. aureus is a gram-positive coccus, not a gram-negative rod.

D) INCORRECT:

Pyelonephritis-associated fimbriae (P-fimbriae) are present on uropathogenic E. coli. a gram-negative rod that causes cystitis and pyelonephritis. E. coli can also cause a lung abscess secondary to pneumonia, but E. coli pneumonia is typically hospital-acquired, and P-fimbriae are not responsible for the pathogenesis of pulmonary infections. Instead, other virulence factors, such as the K capsule, are involved in the pathogenesis of E. coli pneumonia.

E) CORRECT:

Klebsiella pneumoniae possesses a capsular polysaccharide that acts as an antiphagocytic virulence factor and allows bacteria to evade host immune defenses. This pathogen is part of the natural flora of the gastrointestinal tract. In patients who are immunocompromised and patients who have an increased risk for aspiration events (e.g., due to chronic alcohol use), aspiration of Klebsiella can lead to destruction of alveoli, resulting in bloody sputum with a currant jelly appearance.
questions.hint: This patient's sputum culture with gram-negative rods and history of foul-smelling, dark red, gelatinous sputum (currant jelly sputum) is consistent with a pulmonary infection caused by Klebsiella pneumoniae.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of a 3-day history of increasing shortness of breath and chest pain. He has had a productive cough with foul-smelling sputum for 1 week. He has gastritis as well as advanced Parkinson disease and currently lives in an assisted-living community. He smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 40 years but quit 5 years ago. He has a 30-year history of alcohol abuse but has not consumed any alcohol in the past 5 years. His temperature is 39.3°C (102.7°F), he is tachycardic and tachypneic and his oxygen saturation is 77% on room air. Auscultation of the lung shows rales and decreased breath sounds over the right upper lung field. Examination shows a resting tremor. Laboratory studies show:


Hematocrit
38%


Leukocyte count
17,000/mm3



Platelet count
210,000/mm3



Lactic acid
4.1 mmol/L (N = 0.5–1.5)


An x-ray of the chest shows infiltrates in the right upper lobe. Which of the following is the most significant predisposing factor for this patient's respiratory symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Living in an assisted-living community is a risk factor for pneumonia because of the advanced age and reduced functional status of the inhabitants as well as exposure to other sick contacts within the community. However, living in an assisted-living community does not predispose to aspiration pneumonia specifically and this man has a more significant risk factor that should be considered.

B) INCORRECT:

Smoking increases the risk of pneumonia by weakening pulmonary protective mechanisms. It also predisposes patients to chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), which can be a risk factor for aspiration pneumonia. However, this man is not a current smoker, and does not have other features of COPD such as a chronic cough, wheezing, or a barrel chest, making this an unlikely cause of his pneumonia.

C) INCORRECT:

Active alcohol use is a risk factor for aspiration pneumonia, as it may lead to altered consciousness, emesis, and suppressed airway protective mechanisms. Although this patient's past history of alcohol abuse increases his risk for many different conditions, such as hepatic dysfunction and cerebral atrophy, it does not increase the risk for aspiration pneumonia.

D) INCORRECT:

Gastritis commonly presents with epigastric abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting. Complications of gastritis include bleeding ulcers and gastric carcinomas. However, gastritis does not predispose to aspiration pneumonia, as there is no reflux associated with gastritis.

E) CORRECT:

Parkinson disease predisposes patients to aspiration pneumonia by impairing the swallowing and/or cough mechanism in up to 80% of those with late-stage disease. Aspiration is most likely to occur in the dependent portions of the lung (the superior segment of right lower lobe and the posterior segment of the right upper lobe when supine or the apical and posterior right lower lobe when upright). These are often mixed infections involving organisms from the oral flora, particularly anaerobic bacteria (e.g., Peptostreptococcus, Fusobacterium, Prevotella, or Bacteroides).

Other predisposing conditions for aspiration pneumonia include conditions that are associated with altered consciousness (e.g., alcoholism, seizures), apoplexy and neurodegenerative conditions (e.g., Alzheimer disease), gastroesophageal reflux disease, and esophageal motility disorders.
questions.hint: This patient has a high fever, respiratory compromise, cough with foul-smelling sputum, and infiltrates in the right lung, which is indicative of aspiration pneumonia.

questions.text: A 57-year-old man with HIV and GERD comes to the emergency department because of productive cough with malodorous phlegm and night sweats for the past week. He has smoked 1 pack of cigarettes daily for 30 years and he drinks 8–10 beers daily. His temperature is 38.9°C (102.0°F). Physical examination shows coarse crackles and dullness to percussion at the right lung base. Scattered expiratory wheezing is heard throughout both lung fields. The CD4+ T-lymphocyte count is 280/mm3. An x-ray of the chest is shown. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Bronchiectasis is characterized by chronically dilated bronchi and mucopurulent sputum. It is mainly seen in patients with cystic fibrosis and/or recurrent pulmonary infections (e.g., aspergillosis). Bronchiectasis characteristically appears as “tram track” lines or honeycombing on x-ray, due to chronic inflammation and fibrosis of bronchial walls. This patient does not have any risk factors or imaging findings consistent with bronchiectasis.

B) INCORRECT:

Pneumocystis pneumonia (PCP pneumonia) is a common opportunistic infection in patients with advanced HIV/AIDS. Unlike this patient, PCP pneumonia classically presents with a dry cough, diffuse bilateral dry crackles, and interstitial pneumonia on chest x-ray. Additionally, a CD4+ count > 200 cells/mm3 makes this diagnosis less likely.
Image Description:

X-ray chest (left: lateral view; right: AP view) of a patient with a medical history of untreated HIV

Chest x-ray reveals diffuse, patchy interstitial, and alveolar infiltrates bilaterally. The (left-sided) perihilar lung shadowing (also known as “bat wing” or “butterfly opacities”) in AP view is concerning for Pneumocystis jirovecii infection.

C) INCORRECT:
